definitions.definition: To make something happen suddenly and quickly.
examples: to precipitate a journey, or a conflict

definitions.definition: To throw an object or person from a great height .
To send violently into a certain state or condition.
examples: we were precipitated into a conflict

definitions.definition: To come out of a liquid solution into solid form.
examples: Adding the acid will cause the salt to precipitate .

definitions.definition: To separate a substance out of a liquid solution into solid form.
To have water in the air fall to the ground, for example as rain , snow , sleet, or hail; be deposited as condensed droplets .
examples: It will precipitate tomorrow, but we don't know whether as rain or snow.

definitions.definition: To cause (water in the air) to condense or fall to the ground.
To act too hastily ; to be precipitous .

main_definition: ( transitive ) To make something happen suddenly and quickly.
secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To throw an object or person from a great height .
( transitive ) To send violently into a certain state or condition.
( intransitive ) ( chemistry ) To come out of a liquid solution into solid form.
( transitive ) ( chemistry ) To separate a substance out of a liquid solution into solid form.
( intransitive , meteorology ) To have water in the air fall to the ground, for example as rain , snow , sleet, or hail; be deposited as condensed droplets .
( transitive ) To cause (water in the air) to condense or fall to the ground.
( intransitive ) To act too hastily ; to be precipitous .
